computation.contextfreegrammar

Class Variable

  • java.lang.Object
    • computation.contextfreegrammar.Symbol
      • computation.contextfreegrammar.Variable

  • public class Variable
extends Symbol
    Represents a variable, a.k.a. a nonterminal.

    This class is slightly more complicated than the Terminal class. To make your life easier, it is nice to have variables named
    S₀, S₁, S₂,...
    rather than having to use different letters:
    S, T, U,...
    this will become especially clear when you convert a grammar into Chomsky normal form.

    This class allows for variables with subscripts from 0 to 9, and should handle them consistently as if they were different letters. There is also a helper method which will produce an array of variable objects, e.g. I want 3 S variables: S₀, S₁, S₂.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Variable

        public Variable(char symbol)
        Instantiates a new variable with a single character symbol. Automatically converts to upper case.
        Parameters:
        symbol - the symbol for this variable

      • Variable

        public Variable(java.lang.String symbolSubscript)
        Instantiates a new variable with a string, must be of length 1 or 2.

        If length 1, will just initialise as if you called the other constructor.

        If length 2, will use the second character as a subscript.

        e.g. this is valid:
        new Variable("A3");
        this is not:
        new Variable("BB");
        and will throw an exception.

        Parameters:
        symbolSubscript - the symbol subscript
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the string is invalid

    • Method Detail

      • isTerminal

        public boolean isTerminal()
        Description copied from class: Symbol
        Checks if this symbol is a terminal (rather than variable).

        This so we don't have to use instanceof Terminal, though we might choose to for specific reasons.

        Specified by:
        isTerminal in class Symbol
        Returns:
        true if terminal, false if variable

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Symbol

      • subscriptedVariables

        public static Variable[] subscriptedVariables(char letter,
                                              int n)
        This helper method will give you an array of subscripted variables.

        So the following:
        subscriptedVariables('S', 3)
        will return an array of 3 subscripted S variables:
        [S₀, S₁, S₂]

        Parameters:
        letter - the symbol to use for the variables
        n - how many subscripted variables you want, between 1 to 10 inclusive
        Returns:
        an array of subscripted variables
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if not between 1 and 10 inclusive

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String... args)
        A main method demonstrating the use of subscriptedVariables.

        If this doesn't print then your terminal doesn't support Unicode. You can avoid this by simply not using subscripted variables.

        Parameters:
        args - the arguments
